dt: {bc}any of various large usually entirely glossy black passerine birds (family Corvidae and especially genus {it}Corvus{/it})

dt.t: the braggart was forced to eat {wi}crow{/wi}

et: Middle English {it}crowe{/it}, from Old English {it}crāwe{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}krāwa{/it} crow, Old English {it}crāwan{/it} to crow
shortdef: any of various large usually entirely glossy black passerine birds (family Corvidae and especially genus Corvus)

dt: {bc}to make the loud shrill sound characteristic of a cock
{bc}to utter a sound expressive of pleasure
{bc}to exult gloatingly especially over the distress of another

pt: {sc}boast{/sc} {sc}brag{/sc} {sc}vaunt{/sc} {sc}crow{/sc} mean to express pride in oneself or one's accomplishments. {sc}boast{/sc} often suggests ostentation and exaggeration
, but it may imply a claiming with proper and justifiable pride.

pt.t: the town {it}boasts{/it} one of the best museums in the area

pt: {sc}brag{/sc} suggests crudity and artlessness in glorifying oneself.
{sc}vaunt{/sc} usually connotes more pomp and bombast than {sc}boast{/sc} and less crudity or naïveté than {sc}brag{/sc}.
{sc}crow{/sc} usually implies exultant boasting or bragging.

shortdef: to make the loud shrill sound characteristic of a cock
to utter a sound expressive of pleasure
to exult gloatingly especially over the distress of another

dt: {bc}a member of an Indigenous people of the Great Plains between the Platte and Yellowstone rivers
The names {d_link|Apsáalooke|Apsáalooke} or {d_link|Absaroka|Absaroka} are often used by Crow as {d_link|self-designations|self-designation}.
{bc}the Siouan language of the Crow people

et: translation of American French {it}gens des Corbeaux{/it} "crow people," or names of similar meaning in the languages of Plains Indians adjacent to the Crows

The reason for the application of words meaning "crow" or "raven" to the Crow by their neighbors is obscure. The Crow self-designation is {it}apsâˑroˑke,{/it} traditionally rendered in English {it}Absaroka, Apsaroka,{/it} with other variants; it is spelled {it}Apsáalooke{/it} in the practical orthography used by Crow speakers. (The sound written {it}l{/it} is pronounced as a rhotic tap by older speakers.) It is apparently a generalization of an earlier band name and has no etymology, though supposed translations of the word in the 19th and early 20th centuries frequently rendered it as "Crow." See {it}Handbook of North American Indians,{/it} vol. 13, part 2 (Washington, 2001), pp. 714-15.
shortdef: a member of an Indigenous people of the Great Plains between the Platte and Yellowstone rivers
the Siouan language of the Crow people

dt: {bc}a wrinkle extending from the outer corner of the eye

dt.t: The grand old man had a full thatch of white hair, and {wi}crow's-feet{/wi} around pale-blue eyes.
When someone is giving you a true smile, the skin around his or her eyes crinkles up into {wi}crow's feet{/wi}.
One day you're a carefree teenager lolling on a beach. The next you're counting {wi}crow's feet{/wi} in the rearview mirror …

shortdef: a wrinkle extending from the outer corner of the eye —usually plural

dt: {bc}a partly enclosed platform high on a ship's mast for use as a lookout

shortdef: a partly enclosed platform high on a ship's mast for use as a lookout; also : a similar lookout (as for traffic control)

dt: {bc}a uniformly black crow ({it}Corvus corone corone{/it}) occurring in much of western Europe

shortdef: a uniformly black crow (Corvus corone corone) occurring in much of western Europe

dt: {bc}racial {d_link|segregation|segregation} and discrimination enforced by laws, customs, and practices in especially the southern states of the U.S. from the end of {d_link|Reconstruction|reconstruction} in 1877 until the mid-20th century

dt.t: The percentage of blacks living in the South fell from 89 percent in 1910 to 53 percent in 1970 as millions migrated to the Northeast and Midwest to escape {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} and acquire a better standard of life.

dt: {bc}the laws requiring racial segregation that were enacted under Jim Crow

dt.t: The explicit sanctioning of segregation by {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} meant that black public schools lacked of resources and public funding—shortcomings that limited the skill sets and education levels of young, black men during this period, which in turn limited their job opportunities.
It took the Civil War, the Fourteenth Amendment, and the repeal of {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} for the most egalitarian society on earth even to begin to narrow the gulf between principle and practice.

All the women … who marched or canvassed during the civil rights movement helped bring about the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the 1965 Voting Rights Act, which ended {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} and enfranchised Southern blacks.

In 1926, while traveling by train from Wilmington, N.C., to Richmond, Va., the Jamaican-American writer J. A. Rogers was forced to ride in the wooden {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} car {gloss}=segregated car required by Jim Crow laws{/gloss}, which was typically placed toward the front, behind the engine and ahead of the steel cars reserved for white passengers.

Although such segregation has been banned since the late 1960s by federal, state and local public accommodations laws, civil rights activists say {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} still exists here, largely unnoticed and unchallenged.

dt: {bc}racism personified {bc}racist systems or beliefs imagined as a person

dt.t: But [Congressman George H.] White understood that, in fact, {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} was determined to maintain the power structure of the plantation economy by any means necessary.

aq.auth: William J. Barber II and Jonathan Wilson-Hartgrove

dt.t: But in 1883 the Supreme Court had cast aside the law, saying that not even the equal protection clause of the 14th amendment gave the Congress the power to outlaw racial discrimination among private individuals. That is one of the openings via which {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} dug in after the end of slavery.

et: {it}Jim Crow{/it}, stereotype Black man in a 19th century song-and-dance act
shortdef: racial segregation and discrimination enforced by laws, customs, and practices in especially the southern states of the U.S. from the end of Reconstruction in 1877 until the mid-20th century —often used before another noun —called also Jim Crowism
the laws requiring racial segregation that were enacted under Jim Crow — often used before another noun
racist systems or beliefs —called also Jim Crowism

dt: {bc}to restrict the liberty of (someone) through {d_link|Jim Crow|Jim Crow:1}

dt.t: I also like it because we've got subways and it does not take all day to get downtown, neither are you {wi}Jim Crowed{/wi} on the way.

[Frederick] Douglass was {wi}Jim Crowed{/wi} on railroads, on steamboats and in hotels more times than he could count, but loved the Declaration of Independence, the natural-rights tradition and especially the reinvented Constitution—the one rewritten in Washington during Reconstruction, not the one created in Philadelphia in 1789.

shortdef: to restrict the liberty of (someone) through Jim Crow — usually used in passive constructions
